div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

TTvDaI Weisaenstein Castle (3401 Jf X Ule feet). Fireglass. Private Hotel/ near Windisch-Matrei station, T-i«nr ( Easily reached from Trieate or Venice. ) Bracing air. Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. Photos and Prospectuses at “Egyptian Gazette” office, Cairo. 2921s—*o*-a-»o7

minary study, and consequently the interests of the varion* corporations will , not be sufficiently taken intoXxrasideration. This is, however, quite erroneous. The Egyptian Government has always made a point of consulting the import and export trades of Alexandria before taking any measure that might jeopardise thfiir interests. We have no doubt bat that the Government will do so in the present case. As to the position of the Alexandria Municipality in this matter,, we need merely state that the only step that has up to now been taken has been the communication to that body of the project of the new branch of the Canal. This scheme was submitted to the Municipality a few months ago in order to be studied by the members of the Municipal Commission. It was carefully drawn up by the able engineering authority* of the Ports and Lighthouses-Administration, M. Malavel, who' may be called the originator of the idea of the now branch. - The project has not yet been brought officially to the cognizance of the members of the Municipal Commission. One of the first conditions that the Municipality was prepared to insist upon was that in no way should the free flow of the existing canal be impeded lest in any case the purity of the present intake of the Alexandria Water Company should vbe endangered by having a stagnant body of water existing below the site of the intake. Since then the question- has remained in statu quo. The Government has now to give a decision on the matter, and will then doubtless consult the Municipality in order to take its opinion as to the advisability of proceeding with the projeot. An regards the Irrigation Department, trie scheme for a new maritime canal has been brought'to the notice of the Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt, but as yet no definite steps have been taken. A new branch does not offer any objection from the point of view of irrigation, as it does not entail the Irrigation Department’s giving any more water, which is the main consideration with that department.

The actual scheme is the construction of a new salt-water canal running at ses level from Gabbari to Nouxha, where it would step up to the canal level by means of locks. It is obvious that such a scheme has many advantages. It prevents the silting up al the harbour, will improve the railway comniunications, relieve the congestion on the Mahiuoudieh Canal, and improve the sanitary condition of the port During the last four years the number of boats passing through the Menoufieh head lock at ' the barrage has more than quadrupled and the number of boats passing through the tail lock of the Mahmou- dieh Canal shows a similar increase. In 1905 the number of boats passing Kafr Da war up and down stream was 30,438, and annually 20,500 boats ply on the Nquxha*Mii«et-el- Bassal reach. The congestion grows worse every day, and the construction of the new branch is imperative, for it is the only solution out of the difficulty. Alexandria is growing rapidly, and will inevitably become not only the great outlet tor Egypt's railway traffic, but tor the greater part of Africa. The Cape-to Cairo Railway scheme may yet be far from being a “fait accompli,” but there is sure to be a complete system of communications between North and South Africa by rail, river, and lake in a few years’ time, and the outlet for this traffic will be at Alexandria. The growth of the town westward will In a few years’ time lead to one uninterrupted mass of buildings stretchingJrora Gabbari to Mex and occupying every available site between sea and lake. Unless, therefore, a decision is arrived at soon the scheme will not be feasible without enormous extra cost for expropriations. At the present time the land-owners interested in the promotion of the project are prepared to cede to the Egyptian Government free of any charge, the land necessary for making the new branch and they are ready to construct the canal under the supervision of the Government. They further offer to give facilities for connecting tie goods station at Gabbari through the Gabbari quarter with the new ways to the west Under such favourable conditions .the new maritime canal could easily be constructed, and it is to be hoped that the Government will not lose the opportunity, for soon, owing to the rise in the value of the land consequence on the development of the ffity westward, the canal will never have a chance to be made without very great expense.

The Plague Yesterday's plague at Iitnailia Public Holiday. The Government Departments will be closed to-morrow (Aooeaaion Day). Return of H M.8 Venue H.M 8. Venus will arrive at Alexandria on Wednesday and proposes to remain about a week. Hellenlo War Budget The Hellenio Parliamentary session olosed on Saturday, after voting the war budget of 20,009,000 drachma1. Dellngat Markaz The new Market at Delingat comprises 25 villages, 18 of whioh were formerly comprised in Itai el Baroud Market and 7 in the Markaz of Korn Hamada. Seamen's Home, The annual New Year's Tea and entertainment which it given by the ladies of Ramleh to the seamen in port will take place on Tuesday, 22nd inst Fever In Prison. Owing to fever being prevalent in the Cairo prisons, the authorities have deoided to prohibit the prisoners from being visited by their relatives until further notice. The Weather, The thick fog which prevailed at Alexandria this morning caused a good deal of delay to shipping, the mail and other steamers being unable to enter the pass up to the time of our going to pre*s. Alexandria Amateur Athletlo Club By the coorteey of the committee of the British Club, the annual general meeting of the Alexandria Amatear Athletic Clnb will be held at the British Club on Thursday, 10th inst., at 5 30 p m. Nil* Navigation. A sadd is being constructed from the we*t bank of the Jfjle near Rsneh Barrage. The right side of the river alone is open for navigation and red lights have been fixed for night traffic at the end of the sadd. Murdered by Robbers A few days ago. a gang of robbers broke into an esbet near Nahieh Sejin, belonging to Bogbos Pasha Nobar, and mcrdered thegbeffir stationed there. Three of the gang have been arrested, bat the rest are still at Urge. Haklma (or Khartoum The 8odsn Medical Department is arranging for a Hakima, attached to the Civil Hospita1, to reside in 'Khartoum. This is solely in the interests of the families of married Government employes and families of officers of the Egyptian Army.

Cairo Bourse It is romoored that some members of the Committee of the Stock and Sharebrokers' Corporation at Cairo are eager to negotiate with an important firm ot Cairo brokers with ^ view to ooming to terms in order to settle the dispute which baa dragged for some considerable time now.

Military Lecture. Tbe seventh military lectare of the winter season will be delivered by Captain J. A. j Byrne, 2nd Royal loniskilling Fusiliers, on | AwJ'Vk"™40°wom ‘0* 10 LE" lroro,’’ at 6 p.m. on Tuesday evening next, in tbe Model Room at Headquarters, Cairo.

Exonarated. Salatna Eff. Sarkis, Moawin of Miniah Mon dirieh, who was recently charged with embeszling a sum of Qoyernment money and with certain irregularities,has now been exone-the charge by tbe Supreme Council in of Discipline held at tbe Ministry of the ordered to resume Uiiadel and Mcbamed Aly

Arabic Art The Committee for the Preservation of Monunments ol Arabio Art has only jnst issued the report on its work during 1905. The most interesting reading in tbe report is teappen dix by Henry Bey on tbe mosque El Mardani, that exquisite specimen of Arabic art of tbe fourteenth century in the Darb el-Ahmar. It WM one of the finest edifices created during the reign of Bn-Nasr ibn Kalsoon, and like many other mosques in Cairo had been falling into ruin, but has now been restored. Tbe article is well illustrated.

The Bulletin of the "Temps” deals with the question of Egypt. It considers it certain that England, when she judges Egypt riper for autonomy, will grant it to her. It remains for tbe Egyptians to prepare a liberal fotnre for themselves by peace and industry. (Havas)

COLLISION AT SUEZ (FROM OUR CORRKSPONDIMT.) Suez Sunday. Yesterday morning, at 1 o’olock, while the Dutch steamer Timor was under weigh in 8urz roads to enter the Canal, the S.S. Knowsley Rail, which was at the time coming on to her anchorage from the Red Sea, ran into her and damaged her amidships, above the water line. Tbe damage would have been mnoh greater, however, had the latter steamer not reversed her engines.

DUKE OF CONNAUGHT'S VISIT We are authorised to contradict the state men of a morning contemporary to the effect that the Dike of Connaught, on the occasion of his forthcoming visit to Egypt, will stay at Abdeen Palace.

THE KHEDIVE H II. the Khedive, who spent yesterday at Konbbeh Palace, went this morning to Ismailia to inspect his estates there. His Highness returns to Koubbeh this evening, and to-morrow morning will go to Abdeen, to hold the anunal reception on the anniversary oi his HighneBs’s accession.

THB SUCRERIES COMPANY On Saturday last the hearing of the case of A. Felonioo and partners against the adminis tration of the Supreries Company was postponed until the 29th proxo., when it will come on for hearing before a special sitting of tbe Commercial Mixed Court at Cairo

UNION FONCIEUE The Union Foncifrre d'Egypte has just oon eluded an excellent purchase of the finest agricultural land in the Behera Province from tbe Daira Rbassa, tbe Daira having sold 2,300 feddans to the company

THE EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITY. Theoommittee of tbe proposed University, composed of 15 members, have decided to inorease their number to 25, by selecting 10 more aotive members, two of whom will be Dr. Alwi Pasha and Yonssef Bey Saddik. Hassan Pasha ohsen and Hafi Bey Hl Mansbawi have subscribed £500 and £100, respectively, to the funds.
